prose:
The first thing I saw was the stamp. It came down on the form with a sound of finality—*thwump*—and the matter was closed. **To see is to use your eyes to look at something**, and what I saw was a bored clerk sliding the paper back across the polished counter.

“I’m afraid that’s not possible. The regulations are quite clear,” he said, not looking at me. “The office closes at five.”

I knew I would **need** to try another approach. **To need is to require something**, and I required that stamp. But first, I had to get out of there. I turned and began to walk quickly toward the door. **To walk is to move by putting one foot in front of the other**, a simple act that felt suddenly dangerous.

Outside, the air was thick with panic. “Evacuate!” someone shouted. “Flee!” I knew I had to **run**. **To run is to move fast using your legs**, and I did, my shoes slapping against the cobblestones. I needed to reach the designated point, a thought that echoed in my head like another’s voice: “NEED TO REACH MY DESIGNATED RECHARGE POINT.”

I ducked into a dim café, sliding into a booth. At the next table, a man in a worn suit was holding court. “Must be nice to be Préfet of the Hexagon,” he sneered to his companion, “and have your biggest problem surround some missing ceremonial sword.” He took a long drink. “The Préfet better not drink from that Durendal. Who knows how many hands have touched it while it was missing? Reusing glassware is the best way to catch something.”

His friend nodded, swirling his own glass. “One finds a certain… satisfaction in a properly maintained Route Nationale,” he mused. “If you’re on a Route Nationale, you can usually outpace anything. Provided you’re in decent shape, and not weighed down by paperwork.”

Paperwork. The word was a cold stone in my gut. I knew what I had to do. I stood and approached their table. “I can help you with your… anarchist problem,” I said, my voice low.

The first man looked up, eyes sharp. “You get rid of those Anarchists. All of them. If you can take care of that for me, I’d make it worth your while.”

I gave a slow, bureaucratic nod. **To give is to hand something to someone**, and I gave him only my coldest demeanor. “Very well. I will file the appropriate Form 7-B: ‘Request for Anarchist Disposition’ through the proper channels. The paperwork will require your signature in three places.”

He stared, then burst out laughing. “Hmph. The bureaucracy.” He tossed a heavy key onto the table. “There. The back door of the sous-préfecture. That’s what you really need, isn’t it?”

**There**—in that place, on the scarred wood—lay my solution. I took the key. **To take is to get hold of something**, and this was everything. As I slipped out into the alley, I heard the man’s final warning call after me: “Are you prepared to initiate the next phase of your compliance review?”

I didn’t look back. I just ran.
